stealing, on the 1st of October , 1 saw, value 1s.; 1 stock and bit, value 2s.; 1 holdfast, value 18d.; 1 bed-wrench, value 6d.; 2 chisels, value 1s., and 1 screw-driver, value 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Harris
.

THOMAS HARRIS. I am a bedstead-maker , and live in Bagnigge-wells-road. The prisoner was my journeyman ; he left on the 1st of October, and I missed all these tools - he had no authority to pawn them; I met him on the 21st of October, in Gower-street, and he ran away - I called a Policeman, who took him.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Nichols, pawnbroker, Gray's Inn-lane. I produce all these tools which were pawned by the prisoner, in three pledges; I am certain of him.

ROBERT TURNER
. I am a Policeman. I apprehended the prisoner, and found the duplicates of the tools on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Three Months .

231.
JOHN EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 9 lbs. of bacon, value 5s. , the property of
Patrick Neal
.

FREDERICK MILES
. I am a Policeman. On the 25th of November, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoner and another lad in John's-row
; the lad went into Neal's shop, took the bacon off the counter, and gave it to the prisoner in the passage - they both ran away; I followed, and took the prisoner with it under his arm.

MARY NEAL
. I am the wife of Patrick Neal, of John's-row. I heard the scales rattle in the shop, I ran out, and the bacon was gone; the Policeman brought the prisoner in with it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in the passage; a boy betrayed me from work, and put the bacon into my arms.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Week .

232.
WILLIAM BARNETT
was indicted for
stealing on the 22nd of November , 9 locks, value 27s.; 1 pair of brass butts, value 15s.; 2 bolts, value 8s.; 6 ends for blinds, value 6d.; 1 brush, value 6d.; 1 latch, value 2s. 6d.; 4 locks, value 2s.; 6 drawer-handles, value 18d., and 8 window-rods, value 2s. , the goods of
Hugh Welch Cooper
.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
. I am a Policeman. On the 28th of November, about half-past five o'clock in the morning, I stopped the prisoner in Gray's Inn-lane, carrying a heavy basket - I asked what he had there; he said some furniture to put in a house in Blackfriars-road, and that his father was a master builder; I said I did not believe him - he said I might see what he had got; I examined it, and said I should take him to the watch-house - he took up the basket, walked a few steps, then threw it on me, and ran away; I sprang my rattle, and Haines stopped him in three minutes - I am sure of his person.

WILLIAM HAINES
. I am a Policeman. I was in Bell-court, Gray's Inn-lane, and heard a rattle spring - the prisoner passed me almost immediately; I pursued, and never lost sight of him till I brought him back - he refused to go; there was a struggling between us, and he took hold of the lamp-post, but I brought him back.

GEORGE EVA
. I am foreman to Hugh Welch Cooper, a builder in Wakefield-street, St. Pancras - these things are all his. On the evening of the 21st, at half-past five o'clock, I put them on a shelf in the first floor of his workshop - the door was locked; I found the window forced in next morning, about seven o'clock, and every thing in confusion, from one end to the other; the premises are near the bottom of Gray's Inn-lane.
Prisoner's Defence. I live by King's-cross - I was going to work, and found these things in the fields.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fifth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

233.
MARY ELIZABETH SAGGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of November , 22 books, value 20s. , the goods of
William Brian
; to which she pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 51. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

234.
RICHARD PETERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 1 cloak, value 10s. , the goods of
George Henekey
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY. -
Judgment Respited
.

235.
WILLIAM FARROW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 1900 sheets of printed paper, value 12l. , the goods of
George Smallfield
, his master.
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE SMALLFIELD
, I am a printer , and live at Homerton; the prisoner was in my service for sixteen years and a half. In consequence of having paper burnt, I had occasion lately to take stock; I missed a great number of volumes - I never gave the prisoner permission to take these volumes, and sell them for waste-paper; they are all saleable works - the Rev. Mr. Aspland's hymn forms a part of them, which is a work now on sale.
COURT. Q. Did you ever give him authority to sell waste-paper? A. Not on his own account; he had sold some for me, but certainly he had no authority to sell this - this is not waste-paper.

Cross-examined by MR. ROWE. Q. Had you given him permission to sell any other volumes? A.None for himself, he has on my account; I took stock in October last - my business is not very extensive; I have about twelve workmen now - they could go to my warehouse, but the greater part of them had no right to go; no other person has ever sold paper for me.

ALFRED ANDREWS
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. About the 4th of November, 1830, I was returning from Stamford-hill, and saw the prisoner in the high road, going to London, with master's cart; I got up in the cart - there were two bundles of paper in it - he went to Old-street-road, and left the paper at Riley's house; the prisoner gave me 6d. - he had before that spoken to me respecting some paper which I saw him take; he held up his finger, and said, "Never you say a word, or you will ruin me and my family;" that was one day when we took some paper - that was all that passed.

COURT. Q. A word about what? A. About some paper that was in the cart, I suppose; he took some six or seven times - I do not know when he said that; it was some time before, when we were taking paper there.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been in your master's service? A.Three years next May; I do not know where this paper came from - the first time I saw it was at the top of my master's lane; I had before been with him when he took paper - I did not mention this to my master till after the prisoner was in trouble.

JOHN RILEY
. I am a cheesemonger, and live in Old-street. Shortly before Christmas, 1830, the prisoner brought some printed paper to me, in Mr. Smallfield's cart, which I bought of him; it was, I think, between 30 lbs. and 40 lbs. - I sold that paper, with others, to Faulkner, Mr. Wilson's man; the prisoner did not make any representation to me - it was in two bundles, and I paid him 3d. per 1b. for it; I sold some of the best at 4 1/2d. per 1b., and used the inferior part at my own place.
Cross-examined. Q. At what hour of the day was this? A. He generally came between ten and one o'clock- I saw his master's name on the cart, and he brought it openly into the shop.

WILLIAM FAULKNER
. I am servant to Mr.
Gilbert Wilson
- he lives in Upper Thames-street, and deals in waste-paper. I bought some paper of Mr. Riley the latter end of March, or the beginning of April; I took it home to my master's - I remember Mr. Smallfield coming and seeing the same paper which I got from Riley - this is it; I am sure it is part of what I bought of Mr. Riley.

Cross-examined. Q.What is your master? A. A rag and waste-paper dealer; we buy a great deal from various quarters - we frequently buy volumes of booksellers; I took this home, and it remained there six or seven weeks; I took other paper with this, but of a different size - this is of a particular size; I think this paper remained at my master's from March to October; there is another man who weighs the paper, and stows it away in piles.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you quite sure this is some ofthe paper you got from Mr. Riley's? A. I am quite confident of it.

MR. SMALLFIELD. I have no hesitation in saying that this is the property of the Rev. Mr. Aspland, intrusted to my care - I never authorized the prisoner to sell it; it is gathered into volumes - these are half volumes.

Cross-examined. Q.Can you possibly identify this paper as coming out of your possession? A.Certainly; I have the work in this state for sale, and send it in this state to different booksellers, when I have orders for it - there is a running account between me and the prisoner - I cannot state the balance, but there was never any running of the paper sold by him; he always brought me the money for that; the account was only 1s. a we he requested me to keep for him against his - I do not often send out copies of books which are out of point, not oftener than once in two or three years; I have not taken stock of some of my articles for three or four years, but I think I have of this work.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you ever give him permission to sell Mr. Aspland's hymns? A. No, never.

COURT. Q. Did you ever give him liberty to take paper and sell it without showing it to you? A. Never- this had not been considered as waste-paper; this had been in my possession ever since the prisoner has been with me; it is not much in demand, as there are two cheaper editons - this had lain by, and I was less likely to have my attention called to it.
The prisoner received an excellent character.
GUILTY . Aged 51.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

236.
JOHN VELLELEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of November , 21 lbs. of brass, value 5s. , the goods of
George Green
and others, his masters.

WILLIAM JUDGE. I am a Thames Police-officer. I met a woman in the Commercial-road, on the morning of the 17th of November, carrying something very heavy under her cloak; I stopped her, and found it was ingots of brass - I went to Mr. Green's yard, and saw the prisoner standing outside the gate; he asked me and my brother officer who was wanted: I said, "
John Velleley
" - he then begged of me not to let the firm know; I said,"We must:" I heard him tell my brother officer, that he got the metal out of the yard, and he acknowledged at the office, that the woman was his wife.

THOMAS GRAY
. I was with Judge, and saw the prisoner near the prosecutor's yard; I asked where he got the metal which his wife was carrying - he said he got it from Mr. Wigram's yard, and gave it to his wife to get a trifle.

NATHANIEL CATON
. I am in the employ of George Green, Wigram, and Green - the prisoner was nearly four years in their employ, as a journeyman: I cannot swear to the brass, but I believe it to be theirs - I have fitted these ingots to the moulds, and they fit exactly.
Prisoner. I am sorry for it, they have been good masters to me - I have a wife, and two children.
GUILTY . Aged 32.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

237.
MARY WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of November , 1 half-crown, the money of
William Jackman
, from his person .

WILLIAM JACKMAN
. I am a sawyer . On the 27th of November, I was walking up Oxford-street
with some friends, about one o'clock in the morning; I had had a glass or two of liquor, but I was not intoxicated - the prisoner spoke to us, said she was very cold, and asked us to give her something to drink; we went to the Three Tuns, and had three half-quarterns of gin, and two pints of porter - we went out, and the two young men who had been with me went away; I went up a mews with the prisoner - I felt her hand in my left-hand pocket, where I had a shilling and a half-crown; I felt my pocket, and the half-crown was gone - I said, "You have taken my half-crown;" she denied it; the Policeman came up, and took her - she said at the office that she had one half-crown, but it was her own.
Prisoner. He asked the other men to pay for the gin and beer, and said he had no money. Witness. Yes, I did, but I had put this money by to pay away.

JAMES BARTON
. I am a Policeman. The prosecutor charged the prisoner with robbing him; he was quite sober; the prisoner said she had a half-crown belonging to herself, and she gave it up at the watch-house from her pocket, she had no more money about her.

Prisoner's Defence. He accused me of robbing him, and held my two hands; I said, "What are you going to do?" he felt his left-hand pocket, and said, "You have robbed me of half a crown;" I said, I had not; I thought he was going to strike me, and called the Policeman myself - it is my first offence.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

238.
WILLIAM WATTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of November , 2 pairs of shoes, value 10s. , the goods of
James Rowe
.

JAMES ROWE. I keep a sale-shop , at Kensington
. I took the prisoner in out of charity till he got a situation; we parted on the 5th of November - I missed my shoes, and found this pair on him.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe his parents are in great distress? A. I went into their house that evening, they did not seem so; I know these shoes are mine.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Six Weeks .

239.
OBADIAH WOODCOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of October , 12 ounces of silk, value 1l. 4s., and 9 wooden bobbins, value 9d. , the goods of
George Devereux Ford
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

MARY ANN MACREE
. I am the daughter of
George Macree
; he lives in Great George-street
, and is a weaver. On the 24th of October I was standing at our door; I saw the prisoner another man, and two little boys were looking at their window; the prisoner went by and stood at the prosecutor's door, talking to another man, and the little boy looked out, and said, "Is that you father?" the little boy ran down stairs, and they asked him whether his name was Ford; he said Yes - they said "Where is your father?" he said out; they said, "Is he gone to the public-house?" he said he did not know - they asked if he was gone to the watch-house; he said he did not know - theytook him as far as the corner of the street; the other man then went up stairs with the boy - the prisoner staid at the door about a minute, and then he went in and shut the door; the prisoner went up stairs; I heard the hobbins fall on the floor - the little boy screamed out murder, and said, "Pray don't, I shall be murdered when my father comes home" - I called my father down, and said there were two men robbing Mr. Ford; he ran down, and saw the other man run away - he ran, but could not catch him; I saw the prisoner come out, and cried out Stop thief! and the patrol stopped him six or seven doors from the prosecutor's house.

ROBERT FORD
. I am the prosecutor's son. I saw the prisoner and another man come into my father's room, one Monday night; I was looking out at my father's window, and said, "Is that you father?" the prisoner said, "I am not your father, but I want to speak to you;" I went as far as the end of the street, and then I said, "I must not go any farther;" we came back, and they both went up stairs; the other man pretended to be looking at my cap, and he went behind my father's shelf, and filled his pockets with shute; the prisoner then came up - they whispered together, and this prisoner put the bobbins in his hat, with silk on them - then he took a handkerchief out of his pocket, put shute into it, and tied them up; I said, "Oh, don't take my father's shute, I shall get murdered" - he said, "The more you halloo, the more I'll take;" I said, "Murder! thieves! thieves! murder! they have got my father shute;" they then run away - when the prisoner had got two or three doors off, I saw the officer take him; the bobbins were found at the foot of the stairs.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you lose sight of me? A. No; when you ran down stairs I looked out of window and saw you - I am sure he is the man that took my father's shute.

GEORGE DEVEREUX
FORD. I am the witness' father. I went out on the 24th of November, but I left my work safe, and when I came home I missed nine bobbins of shute; I found three of them at the foot of the stairs, at the bottom of the passage - the other six are lost; they are worth 24s. or 25s. - if the thief had not been found I should have lost my character for ever.
COURT. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. I never knew him before.

Prisoner's Defence. I had a pint or two of beer at the corner of the said street, and as I was going past I heard the two boys call out; I went into the entry to hear what was the matter, and a man rushed out in his shirt sleeves, he took me, and said, "You have been at the work;" I said, "You are mistaken;" he went to get his clothes on, and the patrol took me.

BENJAMIN CRISPIN
. I took hold of him at the foot of the stairs, and he dropped the bundle where it was found.

GUILTY . Aged 42. -
Transported for Seven Years .

240.
JAMES YOUNG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 5s. the goods of
Charles Fentum
, from his person .

CHARLES FENTUM
. On the 9th of November I was on Westminster-bridge
- I did not feel any thing taken, but the officer spoke to me; I missed my handkerchief, which the officer had.

JAMES WILD
. I am a Police-officer. I had watched the prisoner for nearly half an hour - there were one or two more with him; they were trying several gentlemen's pockets - I saw the prisoner take this handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket; I seized him, and took it from him, the other got away.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take it from the prosecutor's pocket? A. Yes, and I took it from your waistcoat.(Property produced and Sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

241.
ROBERT BUTLER
was indicted for
bigamy .

MARY ANN ELDRIDGE
. I know the prisoner - he married my sister
Elizabeth Eldridge
; she is alive, and is here; I was present at their marriage, at St. George's church in the Borough, on the 17th of April, 1820.

SAMUEL PRENDERGAST
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. I produce the certificate of the first marriage - I examined it with the book, and found it correct - (read); I took the prisoner in Gravel-lane.

JOHN PAUL
. I am clerk of All Souls', St. Marylebone, and have the register of marriages. On the 28th of September, 1825 .
Robert Butler
, batchelor, and
Elizabeth Swinford
, widow , were married in that church - I believe the prisoner to be the man.

MARIA CORNISH
. I know
Elizabeth Swinford
; I was in the church, and saw them married - the prisoner is the man; I did not see them again till I saw them over the water - I had known Elizabeth Swinford for some time - her first husband's name was Joseph Swinford.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Had you known the prisoner before? A. Yes, between eleven and twelve years.
COURT TO MARY ANN ELDRIDGE. Q. Did you know any thing of the second wife? A.Sir, I did not.

Cross-examined. Q.Had you been in the daily habit of seeing the prisoner after his marriage with your sister? A. Yes; my sister had a child in about eleven months; they did not live together above two years - a man named Cain has been acquainted with my sister; I have seen them together - I have not visited them: they have visited me; I do not know that my sister ran away to live with Cain, and that Cain came and thrashed the prisoner to make him keep the child - nor that my sister was taken before a Magistrate by the prisoner for ill-treatring him - or that the prisoner was turned out of his house, and all his working-tools taken from him by Cain, at the instigation of my sister - I have seen children at Cain's; I do not know that they were my sister's but they passed as such.
GUILTY . Aged 32.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Confined 1 Month .

242.
JEREMIAH SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d. the goods of
Thomas Hill
, from his person .

THOMAS HILL. I am a sail-maker . On the 11th of November I was in Ratcliff-highway
, between six and seven o'clock at night; I felt something at my right side - I turned, and saw the prisoner; he put his face close to me, and said, "What do you want with me?" I said Nothing - he repeated it again and I said Nothing; I then felt my pocket, and missed my handkerchief; Isaid, "I have lost my handkerchief;" he said, "I saw two urchin thieves on the other side of the way;" he walked with me a little way, till we came to a light; I saw a bulk in front of him, and my handkerchief was hanging down - he walked on to a turning which was no thoroughfare; he turned to go down - I seized him, and cried Stop thief! he struck me - he had a black handkerchief in his hand; I took my handkerchief from under his coat.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Did he not ask whether you had lost a handkerchief? No - he was intoxicated, but could walk very well.

JOHN EASTERBROOK
. I am the officer. I saw the prisoner with this black handkerchief in his hand, and the prosecutor gave me this other.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence I was going to see a friend, and I saw this handkerchief on the ground - I took it up, and walked on; when I came to this street I turned, and the gentleman came up to me; I said, "What do you want?" he saw this handkerchief hang down - he caught hold of it; I took it out, and gave it to him.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

243.
WILLIAM TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of October , 7 knives, value 15s. , the goods of William Day
, his master.

FREDERICK WILSON MILNER
. I am a Policeman. On the 23rd of October I saw the prisoner in the Strand, showing some new knives to another boy, and having seen him before in bad company, I took him; he said his father made the knives, and sent him out to sell them - he begged hard of me to go to his father with him, to convince me that what he said was true; I went with him, and as soon as he got to the house he ran up stairs as fast as he could - I heard him say, "Mother - knives - say you gave them to me;" I went up, and he then said he found them in Covent-garden-market - I took him to the watch-house, and found these seven knives on him.

WILLIAM DAY
. I am a cutler , and live in the Strand
. The prisoner has been in my service about three months - he slept in the shop, and had access to all my drawers; I had sent him on an errand about a week before he was taken, and he never returned; these are my knives - I have some others in my pocket; they correspond exactly.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Do you swear to them by the maker's name? A. I gave an express order to a man to make these particular knives for me, and they have the stamp on them - I swear they had not been sold.
Prisoner's Defence. I never said such a word to my mother.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character, one of whom stated that he would take him as an apprentice.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Whipped and Discharged.

244.
JOHN BOYD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 whip, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
George Muir
.

GEORGE MUIR
. I left my gig in the Edgware-road
on the 12th of November - I left my whip within the apron of the gig, and the reins tied round it; I went into a shop at the corner of Store-street, and the officer produced my whip to me.

RICHARD HANCOCK
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner take the whip; I pursued, and took him with it under his right arm - I was in plain clothes.
Prisoner. Q.Was there any person with me? A. There was another in company with you.
Prisoner. It was the other boy took it; he gave it to me, and then ran away - I told the officer so.

RICHARD HANCOCK
. I saw the prisoner take it.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .

245.
WILLIAM ADAMS
was indicted for
stealing on the 10th of November , 1 pencil-case, value 2s , the goods of
Samuel Avila
.

JAMES LOCKYER
. I am shopman to Samuel Avila, a pawnbroker , of Mile-end-road
. On the morning of the 10th of November I saw the prisoner at a broken pane of glass in our window; he had some kind of instrument - I saw him drawing out a pencil-case, and when he had very nearly got it out, I ran out, and pursued him; I saw about three others near him, as he was running - I took him; and as he was going to the watch-house, he threw away a pencil-case; he left this piece of whalebone, with a book to it, in the window.

JOSEPH WILLIAMS
. I was standing at my door, and saw the prisoner being taken to the watch-house; I saw him throw away this pencil-case.

JOSEPH FRIANEL CRISTALL
. I am a police-officer. I was at the station-house when the prisoner was brought in; I found on him a handkerchief and 1s.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Transported for Seven Years .

246.
JOHN ARUNDEL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of November , 1 cloak, value 35s, and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
Susannah Bruce
.

JOHN ELLIS
. I am a watchman on Westminster-bridge
. I met the prisoner on the Middlesex end of the bridge on the 20th of November, after nine o'clock at night; I saw him go and take this bundle out of a four-wheeled chaise, it was behind the driver - he had his right hand on the spring of the chaise as it passed me, and then I saw his left hand draw the bundle out; I took him - the chaise went on, but I advertized the property, and found the owner.

SUSANNAH BRUCE
. I am a widow , and live in Alfredplace, Bedford-square; this cloak and handkerchief are mine - I was in the chaise, returning from Vauxhall, about nine o'clock in the evening; the parcel was in the back of the chaise - I did not miss it till I got home; I know no thing of the prisoner.
Prisoner's defence. I saw the bundle in the road, and the watchman came and took me; I never had it in my hand.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

247.
JAMES WALEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 3 loaves of bread, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
David Hood
.

SAMUEL MOSELEY
. I live with Mr.
David Hood
; he is a baker - I was out with his bread on the 25th of November; I left my basket at the corner of Portman-square
for about ten minutes - when I returned, I missed three loaves; I saw the bread and the prisoner in custody - these are the loaves.

HENRY GARNET
. I am a Policeman. On the 25th ofNovember, I saw the prisoner on the square side, with these loaves under his arm; when he saw me he ran fast -I went and took him, and asked where he got the bread; he said, "Where did I get it?" as I was taking him along, he threw the loaves into a basket at the corner of Orchard-street, and said, "What is a fellow to do?" he said he had had nothing to eat for two days - he had not a farthing on him, and was nearly naked.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the greatest distress, and seeing the basket, I took them; I should not have taken three, but they were stuck together.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Three Months .

248.
EDWARD UPCHURCH
and
MARY ALBERDINE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October , 1 sovereign, the money of
John Smith
, from his person .

JOHN SMITH. I am a Chelsea pensioner . On the 21st of October I had a sovereign, which was a part of my pension-money; I went to the public-house where I lodge- I was quite capable of taking care of myself; the two prisoners were sitting by me - I took my sovereign out of my pocket; it was in the corner of my handkerchief - I was going to get it changed; Alberdine took it from me - she gave it to Upchurch, and he went away immediately - Alberdine staid a little time, and I argued with her about the money; they had been sitting by my side, but I took no notice of them - I had not known them before; I did not follow Upchurch, because I had a bad leg - I cried out, and threatened Alberdine; I have never seen the sovereign since.

GEORGE FARLEY. I am a labourer, and a pensioner. I was at the public-house where I lodge - I saw Upchurch, and three of his comrades with him; he went out for half an hour, and then returned with a shilling - the prosecutor was drinking there, and Upchurch said, "I will show as much money as you;" the prosecutor said, "If you will show a shilling, I will show a sovereign" - the prosecutor then showed the sovereign from his handkerchief; Alberdine took it and gave it to Upchurch, who started with it- I ran to the bar; the landlord was not at home - I told his daughter; she said, "What can I do? I can't stop him"- Alberdine then got up to go out; the prosecutor held her for a minute or two, but she got away; they were taken the next morning.
Upchurch. Q. Why did not you accuse me of it? A. I did, and tried to stop you; I had heard you say in the morning where you lodged, and I gave information.

WILLIAM BOWEN
. I keep the Adam and Eve public-house, not the house where this robbery was committed, but Upchurch came to my house the same afternoon, between three and four o'clock - he changed a half-sovereign, and had two or three pots of beer.

ROBERT DUFF
. I am pay-serjeant of the company in which Upchurch is a private in the Scotch Guards. The last money I paid him was 2s. 6d. on the 18th of October - I paid him that for three days, he was under stoppages, and must have been very short of money; I have known him fifteen years in the regiment, his character has been irregular, but I know no dishonesty of him.

HENRY WILLIAMS
. I am a constable. I took Alberdine being informed by the landlord of the Three Crowns, that a sovereign had been lost in his house; when I took her, I asked her if she knew any thing about a soldier? she said No - a little boy, who was there, said, "Yes, he lives at the Royal Oak, at Knightsbridge;" I went there, and found he had been absent two days - I afterwards took him in the guard-room.
Upchurch's Defence. I receive 9s. 4d. a week, but I am quartered, and sometimes it does not cost me 2s. a week for living, because I carry out beer for the landlord.
Alberdine put in a written Defence, declaring her innocence.

UPCHURCH -
GUILTY . Aged 39.

ALBERDINE -
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Six Months .

249.
EDWARD SWEENEY
,
JAMES HENESSEY
, and
DENNIS BUCKLEY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of November , 1 watch, value 25l.; 2 keys, value 3s., and 1 seal, value 5s., the goods of
William Hardy
, from his person .

WILLIAM HARDY
. I am a carpenter . I and my brother were at a beer-shop in Essex-street, Whitechapel
, on the 14th of November; we left the house at ten minutes before ten o'clock at night - the prisoners were in the room while I was; there were forty persons in the room -I was quite sober; when I was leaving the room, I put down my hand and felt my watch chain - as I was coming down stairs, Sweeney and Henessey stood one on each side the door; Buckley was a little before them, going down the stairs before me - I do not know that he did any thing to prevent my going down stairs then, but when he came down to the street door, he stopped the doorway up, to prevent my going out - the other two prisoners were then close by me; we at last got out of the house, and I immediately missed my watch - I did not know which way the prisoners had gone - I looked for them, when I missed my watch, and they were all gone; and the people about said it must be these three young men, as nobody else was a thief; I gave information of them - they were all about me, and hustling me at the time Buckley was stopping the doorway.

Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. I believe this was a smoking-club? A. I believe it is called the Free and Easy club - I do not know whether the prisoners are members, but I saw them in the room; when I got up to go the other persons in the room followed very shortly; no one was near me in going down but the three prisoners - I felt my watch safe while I was in the room, and missed it when I got out at the street door; no one touched me on the stairs but the prisoners - the stairs are narrow; no one attempted to hustle me but the prisoners.

JOHN HARDY
. I was with my brother, and saw the three prisoners there; when my brother was going down Henessey and Sweeney got one on each side of the door, and on each side of my brother, and when they got to the end of the passage Buckley stood with his hand across the door, and they were all close to my brother; I had seen the chain of my brother's watch as he left the room, but the seal was out of sight - when we got into the street I asked him if he had lost his watch; he felt, and it was gone - the prisoners were all gone directly.

Cross-examined. Q.This was a club? A. Yes; there were thirty or forty persons in the room - it was the timeto break up; there were some before and some behind us; I was not exactly close to my brother - I cannot say whether there were any other persons exactly on the stairs besides him and the three prisoners; I was behind my brother- there was no one between him and me; I saw him hustled from the top of the stairs to the bottom - some persons might have gone before me.

RICHARD WELSH
. I am a labourer. I was at the beershop, and saw the two Hardys go down - I saw Sweeney and Henessey stand by the door; the prosecutor had to go down sideways to pass them; I saw Henessey make a grab at him, but there was another person between me and him, and I could not see what happened; they then shoved the prosecutor down stairs into the street - I saw Henessey put something into his own pocket, and when Hardy said he had lost his watch, I said, "It is Sweeney and Henessey."

Cross-examined. Q.Had you been acquainted with the prisoners before? A. No, I only knew them at that place; I never had any altercation with them, to my recollection - I never was before any Magistrate on a charge of assaulting Sweeney's brother, nor Henessey - my brother was; I never used any threat about Henessey, to my recollection.

HENRY COTTON
I am a Police-constable. The three prisoners were taken in company together, in Wentworth-street, about half-past eleven o'clock at night; Hardy gave me a description of them.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find any thing on them? A.About 1l. 0s.7d.; they each had some money - I found no watch.

ABRAHAM SCOTT
. I am a Police-serjeant. I heard Sweeney say at the station-house, "The prosecutor cannot say which of the three took his watch."

Sweeney's Defence. Welsh came to me at Lambeth-street Police-office, and asked if I understood Irish - I said Yes; he then asked me to give the watch back - I said I knew nothing about it; he said it was false, for he saw Henessey take it, and give it to me; before the Magistrate he said he saw him take something, but he did not know what.

Henessey's Defence. Welsh went to Sweeney's mother, and said he saw me take the watch, and put it into my pocket: he said he would go to some gin-shop, stay till the row began, and then he would say some other person took it.
Buckley's Defence. The Magistrate asked Welsh if he saw me by the door, and he said he did not see me at all - I was in the house, having a pint of beer.

SWEENEY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

HENESSEY -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

BUCKLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

250.
EDWARD TYLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October , 1 watch, value 7l.; 2 seals, value 30s., and 1 watch-key, value 10s., the goods of
Henry Vallance
, from his person .

HENRY VALLANCE. I was in Chancery-lane
on the 31st of October - I had hold of Mr. Nuttall's arm: there had been a fire, and we were looking at one of the engines - there was no crowd at that time; I saw the prisoner before me - there was then a rush - the prisoner came up against me; I felt my watch going, and saw him draw his hand from me; I touched him, and said, "You have got my watch;" he got from me - I went again to take him, and he got between two men; I made a rush, and seized him again - he said, "Search me," but the watch was gone.
Prisoner. Q.Did not I say, "Search me?" A. Yes, you did, the second time, but not the first' just as your body passed me I felt the watch go from me.

HENRY CONSTABLE NOTTALL
. I was walking arm-in-arm with the prosecutor; all on a sudden, when one of the engines came up, there was a rush, and we were surrounded - I said to the prisoner, "Let go my arm, or you will hurt it;" he did so, and we got nearly facing each other - a person then brushed past me, and I turned round- Mr. Vallance said, "I have lost my watch;" I saw the prisoner go to two men with his hands closed - the prosecutor touched him, and said, "You have my watch;" he said, "I have not, you may search me;" an officer came up, and he was taken.

CHARLES EVANS
. I am a patrol. I was standing watching the gang - there were four or five of them, and they had hustled three or four persons before they bustled the prosecutor; I heard the prosecutor say he had lost his watch, and took the prisoner.

JAMES PALMER
. I am a patrol. I was standing by, and heard the prosecutor say he had lost his watch - I took the prisoner, but found nothing on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I went to see the fire - I was coming towards Fleet-street, and this gentleman said I had taken his watch.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Life .

251.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 1 hearth-rug, value 4s. , the goods of
Phillip Dawe
.

ELLEN DAWE
. I am the wife of
Phillip Dawe
. This rug was taken off the counter in our shop in Bath-street
, on the 24th of November; I was in the parlour - the officer brought it back in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour.

THOMAS BLAIR
. I am a Police-constable. I saw the prisoner in Old-street, about thirty or forty yards from the prosecutor's carrying this rug in this bag; I received information from a carman, and took him into custody - he said he had got a rug, which he brought from his house at Pentonville, and was going to his uncle's in Blackfriars-road.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you sure he said he got it from home? A. Yes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going down old-street, and turned down Whitecross-street - two men walked before me, and dropped this - I took it up.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Weeks .

252.
SARAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing on the 26th of November , 1 shirt, value 5s. , the goods of
William Goodburn
.

HENRY NICKS
. I am in the service of Mr. William Goodburn - he lives in Union-street, Spitalfields
, and is a pawnbroker . The prisoner came there on the 26th of November, to look at some shirts; I showed her some - she bought one, and went away; she came back in about anhour, and said it did not fit; I showed her some more, and while I was serving her I saw her take one from the counter, and conceal it under her shawl; she then asked if we had any children's things - I said Yes; she looked at some but said they did not suit her; she was then going out - I told her she had something: she said she had not - I brought her back, and took it from her.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you known her before? A. Yes, as a customer; the shop was not particularly dark - this could not have happened by accident; it was under her arm, not in her lap - I believe she has things in pawn with us now.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

253.
JOHN STEWART
and
WILLIAM JEFFERSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of November , 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
Joseph Davison
, from his person .

JOSEPH DAVISON
. On the 12th of November I was in Regent-street, between nine and ten o'clock in the evening- I did not feel any thing taken, but I heard a noise; I turned, and saw the two prisoners laying down on the ground near me; the officer had knocked them down, and had my handkerchief in his hand.

THOMAS HOBBS. I was on duty in Regent-street; I saw the two prisoners and another person with them - I had watched them, and seen them attempting several gentlemen's pockets; I said to my brother officer, "We will follow;" they attempted the prosecutor's pocket several times - Stewart took the handkerchief quite out; the other two were behind him, trying to hide him - I run them all up, knocked them all down, and fell upon them; I secured the two prisoners, and got the cap of the third one, but he escaped.
Jefferson's Defence. It is false; I never was in Stewart's company till we were taken.

STEWART -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

JEFFERSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

254.
JOHN SHEPPARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of October , 1 trunk, value 7s.; 6 frocks, value 4s.; 8 shirts, value 5s.; 3 yards of lace, value 3s.; 2 aprons, value 9d.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s.; 2 night-caps, value 6d.; 1 pair of trousers, value 1s., and 9 pairs of stockings, value 6s. , the goods of
James Goulden
.

JAMES GOULDEN
. I was removing to Petter-street, Westminster, where my wife had taken a room; she had employed the prisoner to remove my things, and I saw him removing some.

JANE GOULDEN
. My husband and I were removing to No. 37, Peter-street, on the 19th of September; one of my lodgers told me the prisoner would carry my trunk and other things for me; I employed him to take them - he carried them on his shoulder, and was to take them to the room: I gave him a clock and white hair trunk to carry, and 6d. for it; it contained the articles stated - he went twice; he never returned the second time, and I never saw him till he was taken on Monday, the 19th of November, when he passed by our house; I have not seen my property since.

SARAH ELLIOTT
. I live at No. 37, Peter-street. - The prisoner brought a trunk to the house, and put it down before the counter in my shop; I told him to take it up stairs to the room Mrs. Goulden had taken; he said he could not take it up, for he was in a hurry to get some more things; he then went away, and returned in ten minutes, with a man in a green coat, and pointing to the trunk, he said, "There is the trunk;" the other man said it had come to the wrong place - I said he should not take it away, if any one took it it should be the prisoner; the prisoner said, "Well mistress, rather than have any words I will take it;" he took it, and I saw it no more.

THOMAS ELLIOTT
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. Mrs. Elliott authorised me to give the trunk to another person.
SARAH ELLIOTT. No, I did not - I said no person should take it but the man that brought it; I thought there was some mistake about it.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Confined Six Months .

255.
HENRY McCARTHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of November , 1 tea-caddy, value 4s. , the goods of
John Clyma
.

DAVID MAHONY
. I am a Police-constable. I met the prisoner in George-street, Lisson-grove, carrying this caddy; I asked him what he was going to do with it; he said he was carrying it to his mother - he ran off; I pursued and took him.

ANN CLYMA
. I live in Lisson-grove, and am the wife of John Clyma. I lost this caddy on the 21st of November; I had seen the prisoner before, and believe I had seen him that day.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that a boy who he knew, had given him the caddy to carry.

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Whipped and Discharged.

256.
JOHN LANCASHIRE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of October , 1 watch, value 15s. , the goods of
Thomas Morgan
.

THOMAS MORGAN. I sleep in the same room with the prisoner, in Great Chesterfield-street, Marylebone
. My watch was in a box, which was not locked; I missed it on the 25th of October - I found the duplicate of it on the prisoner.

DANIEL DUTCH
. I am an officer. I went to the prisoner's lodging, and saw him; I told him the watch had been stolen, and I should search - he said, "You are welcome to search my box, here is my key;" he was in bed: I searched his clothes, and in his watch pocket, I found this duplicate and ten others - he got out of bed, fell on his knees, and said, "I hope you will forgive me, I did it from distress;" he had not a farthing of money.

THOMAS SEAWARD
. I am a pawnbroker, and have the watch, pawned on the 22nd of October, by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Confined Three Months .

257.
WILLIAM LOWE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of November , 1 coat, value 1l. , the goods of
Jonathan Murray
.

GEORGE ELLIS
. I knew Mr. Murray's shop. On the 1st of November I saw the prisoner take a blue coat, which hung outside Murray's shop; I told the shopman, and we both pursued and took him with it.

ROBERT STUPART
. I was shopman to Mr.
Jonathan Murray
, who lives opposite St. Katherine's-dock. This witness told me the coat had been taken - we pursued, and took the prisoner, about a hundred yards off with it.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.

GUILTY . Aged 50. -
Confined One Month .

258
ELLEN LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of November , 2 pairs of shoes, value 4s., and 1 apron, value 2d. , the goods of
Bridget Magner
.

ROBERT ASHBY
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 17th of November, on account of her having sold my wife a duplicate; while we were at the office the prosecutor came, and claimed the apron, and afterwards the shoes which the prisoner wore: she at first denied that the apron was the prosecutrix's, but when she claimed the shoes she said she had lent them to her.

BRIDGET MAGNER
. I live in Harris-street, Marylebone
. The prisoner lodged with me one night - she got up first in the morning, and went out; I then missed my apron and shoes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. Half a dozen people lodged in the same room; it was a wet evening - the landlady told me to go there to sleep, and she lent me these things

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

259.
GEORGE PETERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of November , 1 batten, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Reed
.

WILLIAM REED
. I live in Hare-street, Bethnal-green
, and am a weaver . I lost a batten on the 2nd of November, and found it at Mr. Cluff's: I had seen the prisoner before.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When had you seen it? A. I left it safe at a quarter before twelve o'clock, when I went out.

WILLIAM CLUFF
. I keep a broker's-shop in Cheshire-street. On the 2nd of November, about twenty minutes past twelve o'clock, the prisoner brought a pair of battens; he asked 1s. for them - I did not know they were stolen; I went out from two to four, and when I came home there were fifty people round my house.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you deal in a great variety of articles? A. Yes; I bought the battens of the prisoner, in the name of William Jones - I pay ready money; William Cooper is my servant, and was by my side when I bought them: the prisoner was bailed by the Magistrate.

WILLIAM COOPER
. I am servant to Mr. Cluff. On the 2nd of November the prisoner sold the battens to my master - he asked 1s. for them, which my master gave him; I had not known him before; my master put it down in the book, "Jones 1s."
Cross-examined. Q.Is the book here? A. No - this was about twenty minutes after twelve o'clock; I was not at home when they were claimed.

SAMUEL MOORE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner about four o'clock on the 2nd of November.
Cross-examined. Q.What day of the week was it? A. On Wednesday, Mr. Reed gave me charge of him - he was bailed by the Magistrate.
Witness for the Defence.

ELIZABETH MILLER
. On the 2nd of November I was at work at No. 101, Green-street; the prisoner came there at half-past ten o'clock that morning - he brought home a bird-cage which I had lent him; he left my place from thirty to thirty-five minutes after eleven - Cheshire-street is about a mile and a quarter from there.

HENRY BLUMSER
. I am a silk-mercer, and live at No. 1, Bacon-street, Bethnal-green. On Wednesday, the 2nd of November, I saw the prisoner sitting at his father's table, at dinner, at ten minutes past twelve o'clock; his father lived at No. 3, Cheshire-street - I staid with him till five minutes past one; he did not leave the room the whole of that time, upon my oath.
NOT GUILTY .

260.
JOHN LODGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of November , 3 half-crowns, 4 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Mary Ann Lodge
; and 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Emma Lodge
.

MARY
ANN LODGE
. I am the prisoner's sister. I live with my mother, but not my father; the prisoner has been very much neglected by his father for the last three years, and has lived with us - I had some money in a trunk in the room the prisoner slept in, on the 24th of November; he got up that morning before seven o'clock, and went away: my sister and I had been up at work till two in the morning, and we did not get up till eight - I then missed three half-crowns, four shillings, and one sixpence of mine, and a pair of shoes of my sister's; I went and found him at the top of Golden-lane, between eight and nine o'clock the same evening.

EMMA LODGE
. I am the prisoner's sister. These are my shoes, and I know the money was in the trunk.

JAMES BUCKLE
I am an officer. The witnesses sent for me, and gave the prisoner into custody; he had a new jacket on, which he said he bought in Golden-lane, and he said that he had bought a pair of trousers which he gave to another boy, and the rest of the money he had spent in a coffee shop - he said he might as well take his sisters money as any body's; he has been dreadfully neglected: the two young woman bear good characters, and one of them left her place, at Mr. Baker's, to attend to the prisoner.

GUILTY. Aged 15. -
Judgment Respited
.

361.
JAMES HEALE
and
GEORGE CHAPMAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of November , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Nicholas Brown
.

ALICE BROWN
. I am the wife of Nicholas Brown - I take in washing, and live in North Wharf-road, Paddington
. On the 3rd of November, about three o'clock in the afternoon, I was at my window, and saw the prisoners go by together, and as they passed, Chapman put his hand through the palings, and took down a handkerchief, and the peg flew out - Heale was close to him; I followed them, and saw Heale putting something into his bosom -I said, "Give me the handkerchief," but they got away too fast for me to follow them; I sent a lad after them, and they were taken.

WILLIAM TRENCH
. I pursued the prisoner, and criedStop thief! I lost sight of them, but they were taken the same night.
RICHARD HANCOCK. I am a Police-officer. I saw the prisoner go past the prosecutor, but did not see them take any thing; the prosecutor gave me information; I described the prisoners to McLean.
Heale. You said it was not one of us. Witness. When I was fetched to the watch-house, you were laying down, and I did not know you, but I could swear to Chapman.

DUNCAN McLEAN
. I am a Policeman. From the description given me by Hancock, I knew where to find the prisoners, and took them the same evening.
Chapman's Defence. I was not near the place. I had not been a quarter of an hour with Heale when we were taken.

HEALE -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

CHAPMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

262.
JAMES WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of November , 1 cap, value 1s. 8d. , the goods of
Samuel Moses
.

SAMUEL MOSES
. I am a slop-seller , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. I saw the prisoner on the 19th of November walk into my shop, take a cap down, and walk out; I followed, and took him three houses off, with it.
Prisoner's Defence. It was laying at the door; I did not go into the shop.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Confined One Month .

263.
THOMAS SHEARMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of November , 1 wooden frame, value 2s., an 133 lbs. of soap, value 16s. , the goods of
George Blakeway
.

THOMAS MORGAN
. I live in Great Russell-street. I saw the prisoner on the 29th of November, take this soap and frame from Mr. Blakeway's shop; he either went round the corner, or in at the door of the shop - he carried it across the street, and then put it down on the step of a door and ran away - he was pursued and taken; I know he is the man.

JOHN RYLES
. I am a Police-constable. I heard the alarm, and met the prisoner running; I took him six or seven hundred yards from the prosecutor's.

GEORGE BLAKEWAY
. I live in Great Russell-street
. The soap and frame are mine, and were in my shop; I found them on the opposite side.
Prisoner's Defence. I had nothing to do with it.
GUILTY . - Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.
Confined Three Months .

264.
WILLIAM SINGLE
was indicted for
stealing' on the 30th of November , 1 window sash, value 10s., the goods of
Thomas Rushton
, fixed to a building , &c., against the Statute.

2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Richard Kent Hart
and
William Dodd
.

3rd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
Rowland Wilks
.

AMBROSE TIDMAN
. I live in Hackney-road. I had the care of an empty house; the different persons it belonged to, (who are named in the indictment,) agreed to put me in possession of it, as the ownership was disputed- on the 30th of November I met the prisoner coming out of the house with two sashes in his hand, which I had seen secure the day before, and fixed; I asked what he was going to do with them - he said to get them repaired; the door had been wrenched from the hinges, and taken away, but he had not business there.

CHARLES HOWELL
. I had seen the prisoner at the house several times, and on that day I gave information; I saw him getting the sash out of the frame - I told Tidman, and we went and took him.

GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .

265.
WILLIAM RANDALL
was indicted for
stealing on the 24th of November , 6 spoons, value 3l. 3s. , the goods of
Bezzett Doveton
.

JEMIMA BENTLEY
. I am in the service of Bezzett Doveton, Esq. , of Dorset-place
. On the 24th of November I was coming from the drawing-room; I stopped in a little room, where the lady's maid and the nursery-maid sat at work - I heard a noise down stairs; I ran down, and at the butler's pantry, where the plate is kept, I saw the prisoner, who was a stranger; I asked what business he had there - I callede him a thief, and said, "You are after the plate;" he said, "I am not after the plate - I came to see whether the chimneys want sweeping or dusting;" I said, "Why did not you knock at the door?" he said he got his bread in an honester way than thieving - he took off his jacket, and shook it; I was simple enough to let him go - when he was gone I counted the plate, and missed all these soons - I ran up the steps, and saw him turn into Park-street; I went and got the officer to follow him - he brought him back, but the spoons are lost; I am certain he is the man - the spoons were all safe when he came to our house.

SUSAN BLADWIN
. I am nursery-maid at the house - I saw the prisoner take off his jacket, and shake it; we then counted the plate, and the spoons were missing.

RICHARD AMEY
. I am a Police-officer. Our serjeant gave me a description of the prisoner, and I took him; he said he was not the man, and asked me to let him call his brother - he called his brother, who was not at all like him, and the prisoner got away.

THOMAS ARNOLD
. I am a Police-officer. I took the prisoner on Saturday morning at his brother's house, in William-street; when I inquired for him a woman said he was not there, but I searched the house, and found him there asleep - he denied all knowledge of the plate.

CHARLES LAUGHTON
. I went with Arnold, and took the prisoner at his brother's; what he has stated is correct.

Prisoner's Defence. On the 24th of November I was loading same soot away, and was in doors from half-past two o'clock till half-past four; I then went home, and was at home all night - I went out next morning as usual; I was not out of the way.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, beofee Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

266.
WILLIAM ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of October , 3 spoons, value 30s. , the goods of
John Artindale
; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN ARTINDALE
. I live in Cannon-street-road
. The spoons laid on my sideboard; the prisoner called on the 20th of October - he said he was going to America, and he would take any letter for me - he had called about five years ago, and brought me a letter from my brother; he called again on the 21st of October - I was not at home; my wife asked him in - when I returned I missed the spoons.

THOMAS DELBRIDGE
. I am a pawnbroker. I have three spoons, pawned on the 21st of October, I believe by the prisoner.
Prisoner. Q. Do you say that I pawned them? A. To the best of my recollection.

JOHN EAGLE
. I am a Police-officer. I apprehended the prisoner.

WILLIAM CLAPSON
. I have a certificate of the former conviction of the prisoner, which I got at Mr. Clark's office - (read) - he is the man.
NOT GUILTY .

267.
WILLIAM MAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of November , 1 tea-caddy, value 15s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Sewell
.

MARY ANN SEWELL
. I live opposite the House of Correction, Clerkenwell. On the 25th of November I lost a tea-caddy from my door.

WILLIAM SHEEHY
. I am an officer. I met the prisoner on Eyre-street-hill on the 25th of November; I passed him, looked back, and saw the caddy under his arm, and an old waistcoat round it; I followed him to Leather-lane, and asked where he brought it from - he said from his mother's, at Islington; he could not tell me where she bought it, nor what was given for it; I took him to the station - he then said he would tell the truth, that it was given him by a boy at the corner of a street in Islington.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A boy gave it me to hold while he went to have a pint of beer, but he never came out.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Confined Six Weeks .

268.
JAMES JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of October , 30lbs. of spelter, value 5s. , the goods of the
London Dock Company
.

JAMES GRIFFIN
. I work in the London-docks
. On the 25th of October, about half-past eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner go into the spirit shed; he found the spelter, took some of it, and put it under his trousers; he then went to a pile of wood - I watched him for about ten minutes; Mr. Scott, the warehouse-keeper, came by, and I told him - I then went and asked him what he had done with the spelter - he denied having had any; I told Mr. Scott where I had seen him go; he went and found this spelter there - here are 16 lbs. of it: I have seen the prisoner about the docks, but I do not know that he worked there.

JOHN BARNES
. I found the spelter behind the pile of wood in the yard.

DANIEL CLEMENTS
. I am in the service of the Dock Company. On the morning of the 25th of October, a little before nine o'clock, the prisoner was brought up to the watch-house, with this piece of spelter - he never worked there; the shed where the spelter was was open, and he might make a passage through there, but he had no right there; I have no doubt of this being the property of the London Dock Company.

GUILTY . Aged 60. -
Confined Three Months .

269.
SARAH JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of November , 1 cloak, value 7s.; 1 pair of stays, value 5s.; 2 shawls, value 6s., and 1 bonnet, value 3s. , the goods of
Margaret Thomas
.

MARGARET THOMAS
. I live in Five Inkhorn-court, Whitechapel
; I had known the prisoner eight days. She came to me 28th of November, and said she had a brother who was a bricklayer, and was very well off, in London, but she had lost his direction, and was very much distressed; I took her into my house as a servant - I sell milk ; she staid eight days, and then left me without notice; she went out to the barn as usual, and did not return - I missed these things from the room I slept in.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am a special-constable, at Shoreditch workhouse. On the 26th of October the prisoner was admitted into the house as a stranger, and on the Monday Mrs. Thomas came to inquire if we had such a person - she claimed the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was so much abused that I took any thing I could get hold of, and left my own things there.

MARGARET THOMAS
. She did leave her clothes, but I think they were not so good as mine.
NOT GUILTY .

270.
PETER HART
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of November , 1 coat, value 8s., the goods of
George Donalds
; and 1 pair of pattens, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Liddington
.

GEORGE DONALDS
. I lodge at Mrs. Walker's, in Weather-court, Whitecross-street
. I put away my coat in the drawer on the 21st of November, and on the 22nd it was missing - the prisoner lodged in the same room with me; I saw my coat again at Worship-street on the Thursday following; the prisoner had lodged there about three months.

MARY LIDDINGTON
. I am the wife of Thomas Liddington, and lodge in Phoenix-place, Old-street. On the 21st of November I went to Mrs. Walker's, and left my pattens there - when I called again they were gone.

MARY WALKER
. I keep the house - Donalds lodged there. On the 21st he came down, and put his coat into the drawer as usual - the next morning I heard a quarrel up stairs about missing some things; I then opened the drawer, and missed the coat - I went up, and said, "What have you done with the coat?" Donalds said, "I put it into the drawer;" they then came down, and the prisoner said, "Never mind; I took it - I will make it all right on Saturday night."

JOHN WILLIAM FRYET
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a coat, pawned in the name of John Walker, on the 21st of November, and, to the best of my belief, by the prisoner.

JOHN HARRISON CLARKE
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Old-street. I have a pair of pattens, pawned on the 22nd of November, by a man, in the name of Peter Littleton.

JOHN SLATER
. I took the prisoner, and was going tosearch him, when he put the duplicates of these things on a chair.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 26. -
Confined Three Months

271.
JOHN FREEGROVE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 1 waistcoat, value 4s. , the goods of
Mary Ann Ridley
.

MARY ANN RIDLEY
. I am a widow , and live in Little George-street
. The prisoner came this day fortnight to purchase a waistcoat, and I showed him several - he came again on the 2nd of December with a young man; they asked for waistcoats, and I gave each one to try on - my daughter was in the shop; I went out, and when I returned she said to me, "Mother, they have put something into their hats;" I said, "Young men, if you are honest, you will pull off your hats;" the other one ran away, but the prisoner was detained - when the Policeman came he threw down his hat in the shop, and in it was this waistcoat - I believe the other man took one, but I would not swear it.

EPHRAIM PITT
. I am a Police-constable. I was sent for, and found the prisoner; he had thrown down his hat before I got there.(Property produced and sworn to)

LOUISA RIDLEY
. I have heard what my mother has stated, and it is correct - I saw the waistcoat in the prisoner's hat - he said if I got it out he would kick me, which he did.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, declaring his innocence.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined One Year .

272.
JOHN CRAWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of November , 1 bullock's head, value 2s. 6d., and 1 iron hook, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Harradence
.

JOHN SLATER
. I am a Police-constable. I met the prisoner at half-past six o'clock, on the 21st of November, in South-street, carrying a bullock's head on his shoulder- I said, "What have you got there?" he said he had bought it, but he would not tell me where; I took him to the station-house - a boy brought in this iron hook, and said he had dropped it.

JOSEPH HARRADENCE
. I am a butcher , and live in Chiswell-street
. I saw the head at the station-house, and knew it to be mine; I had missed that and the hook from my shop - I know nothing of the prisoner; he was rather intoxicated.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Confined Three Months .

273.
ANN CLAPTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of November ; 1 necklace, value 10s. , the goods of
Edward Nelson
.

EDWARD NELSON
. I live in West-row, Carnaby-market
- the prisoner has lodged in the house for eight or nine months. My wife was ill, and the prisoner tendered her services to her; I believe her husband is a carpenter- she was in my wife's room about an hour; she was the first person that came out of the room - I had seen this necklace in the room just before, and was informed it was gone - I then went in, and missed it; it had hung on an image, over the mantel-piece.

JOSEPH SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. I received this necklace from the prisoner on the 29th of November.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Month .

274.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 5 sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, and 3 sixpences, the monies of
Matthew Rutherford
, from his person .

MATTHEW RUTHERFORD
. I am a seaman ; I had been to the Commons, and received my wages on the 2nd of December, and met the prisoner in a coffee-shop in Ratcliff-highway
, between one and two o'clock the next morning: I had then fourteen sovereigns, and I changed one - I was not sober when I got to the coffee-shop; I found the prisoner there: she accosted me - she asked for something to drink - I gave her half a crown: she got some rum, and brought me three sixpences in change - I then went with her to her own house: I was there a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes; I counted my money in her house, but I did not give her any thing: I had nothing to do with her - she put her hands into my pocket, when I sat down on the chair; I said, "This will not do for me;" I got up and counted my money, I found I had still my thirteen sovereigns, and I put them all safe into my left-hand breeches pocket; I bade her good night, and was going down - as soon as I got to the stair-head, she came and put her hand into my pocket; I seized her hand, and got eight sovereigns out of it - she got off with the rest and went out; I went out of the house in about five minutes, and found her in custody; I had not given her any money.

JAMES GRAHAM
. I am a Police-constable. I heard a noise, and hastened to the place; I heard the prisoner run up some steps a little way from the house - she said, "Oh God! I have lost my shoe;" she came running towards me; I had a lamp in front of me - I turned the light on, and saw one of her hands grasped; I caught at it, and, to the best of my belief, I heard three sovereigns fall - I then searched her, and found two half-crowns and three sixpences in her bosom; I searched the place and so did others, but we found no sovereigns; the prosecutor said,"That is the girl that robbed me of five sovereigns, two half-crowns, and three sixpences."
Prisoner. Q. Did I not tell you, that he gave me two half-crowns and three sixpences? A. No, you never said any such thing; another officer found 8 1/2d. in her pocket.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor had given her the money.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

275.
JOHN BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of December , 1 cloak, value 20s. , the goods of
Thomas Collins
.

SARAH ANN RISEBOROUGH
. I was in Mr. Collins' shop, opposite the Grove, at Hackney
, on the 1st of December, and saw the prisoner take a cloak from the door, and run away with it; I informed the shopman, who pursued - he was taken to the station-house; I saw him there, and can positively state he is the man.

ROBERT TURNER FRY
. On the 1st of December I saw the prisoner running from the door; I followed him, and called Stop thief! he then turned a corner, and I lost sightof him - he was then stopped by a gentleman; I saw him throw the cloak away - it was brought to me by Tyndale.

JOHN RENSHAM
. I was walking up the Grove, and saw several persons struggling; I made up to them - Fry gave me the prisoner and this cloak.

THOMAS TYNDALE
. I was at work in the garden where the cloak was thrown; I took it up and gave it to Fry.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I have always got my living in an honest way, and hope this will be a warning to me.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Three Months .

276.
JOHN WELSH
and
THOMAS KELLY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of December , 3 lbs. of cheese, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Thomas Gardener
.

THOMAS GARDENER
. I live in Somer's-town
, and am a cheesemonger . I missed a piece of cheese on the 2nd of December, at a quarter-past five o'clock; I looked out, and saw the prisoners in a court near my shop; and at half-past five Welsh came and took another piece; I ran out, and took Kelly at the corner of the court - this piece of cheese fell from his coat; I had seen him and Welsh in company together - I then took both the prisoners to the station-house.

ROBERT WOOLEY
. I am a Police-constable. I received the prisoners, and have the cheese; I asked Kelly how he got it - he said Welsh took it, and gave it him.

WELCH -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Whipped and Discharged.

KELLY -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

277.
BENJAMIN MORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of November , 1 snuff-box, value 14s. , the goods of
George John William Ruthven
.

GEORGE JOHN WILLIAM
RUTHVEN. My father set me up in business as a tobacconist - my shop is at No. 16, Wych-street
. On the 8th of November the prisoner came and asked for half an ounce of returns - I served him; he gave me a shilling, and I gave him change - he then asked to look at a snuff-box in the window - I showed him one, and said the price was a guinea; he then asked to look at another, which was 16s. - he put on the lid, and ran away with it; there was another person with him, and we think he run away with another box - my uncle followed the prisoner, and just as he got to the New-church, in the Strand; the Policeman took him.

THOMAS TIPPER
. I am a Police-constable. On the 8th of November I heard a cry of Stop thief! in Newcastle-street - I followed the prisoner, who was running, and as I was bringing him back a lad gave me this snuff-box, which he said he saw the prisoner throw away.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. It is my first time of being here.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

278.
ELIZABETH LONG
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of November , 2 shirts, value 4s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 1s.; 1 waistcoat, value 3s.; 1 hat, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 6d. , the goods of
John Harris
.

JOHN HARRIS
. I am a seaman On the 19th of November I went with a messmate to the White Swan, in Lower Shadwell
; I had a bundle, containing this property - the prisoner came into the White Swan, and I treated her with a glass of spirits; I went out, and when I returned she and my messmate, and my bundle were all gone - I am sure she is the woman.

GEORGE RIDDELL
. I keep the public-house. The prosecutor came in with the prisoner and another sailor; the prosecutor had a bundle - he went out for a short time, and while he was gone I saw the bundle under the prisoner's arm - she and another female left the house with the shipmate, but whether she took it out I cannot say: the prosecutor came in and asked for his shipmate - I said they had all left.
Prisoner's Defence. I had the bundle, but did not take it out.
NOT GUILTY .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, DECEMBER 8.
Second Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

279.
THOMAS HAGUE
was indicted for
perjury .
MESSRS. ADOLPHUS and PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

The following Documents were put in and read:-Two affidavits made by the defendant, sworn on the 25th of July, 1829, and the 4th of February, 1831, in the cause of Hague against Drury - in the latter of which the defendant had deposed that
George Vandepant Drury
was indebted to him in the sum of 500l. for goods sold and delivered by the deponent, to the said George Vandepant Drury, and at his request - a writ for 500l., returnable on the 15th of April - and a warrant dated the 5th of February, 1831 - the copy of a nonsuit - and the declaration which stated that the plaintiff, Thomas Hague, had become acquainted with various matters and things connected with the defendant (George Vandepant Drury) which if generally known, would be very prejudicial to the defendant, and that upon his undertaking not to disclose the same, the defendant had undertaken to pay him a reward of 500l.; in another count it stated the amount to be due for work and labour - there were other counts stating it to be for money lent, advanced, laid out, &c.; the plaintiff was nonsuited, and to pay costs, 32l. 10s. - the bill of particulars of the plaintiff's demand, dated the 31st of May, 1831, stated it to be for 500l., pursuant to an agreement or promise made to or with the defendant in 1829 - another bill of particulars, dated the 11th of June, 1831, stated it to be "the balance of an account as stated and settled with the defendant."

- DEVERELL. I was attorney for the defendant in this action; he is the prosecutor to-day - I attended a Judge of the Court of King's Bench, upon the delivery of the second particulars of demand - the agent to the plaintiff's attorney also attended; I said the general item as to the balance must be struck out, unless the account was furnished, to which the Judge agreed; they delivered no account at any time, but a third bill of particulars was delivered with that item struck out. On the 15th of June Mr. Justice James Parke made a rule to strike out that item.

GEORGE VANDEPANT DRURY
, ESQ. I am the prosecutor of this indictment, and am the grandson of the late Sir George Vandepant; I spent the early part of my life in the East Indies, till 1806 - I then returned to England,and married a lady in Yorkshire; I went with her to India, and came back in 1813 - I resided at a place called Skelton, in Yorkshire, up to March, 1830, being absent occasionally. I first saw the defendant about thirteen years ago; I saw him as any other person about my house - he then lived at Rawcliffe, a village near me; I was arrested at his suit for an alleged debt of 130l. in 1829 - that was settled; he afterwards commenced a suit for 500l.; I put in bail to that, without being arrested - I never had any business transaction with him, and never purchased any thing of him; I swear that positively - I remember in 1824 his acting as agent to his mother, who kept a little farm near my residence; I purchased 5l. or 6l. worth of straw of her that year, and he acted as her agent - I had no other dealings whatever with him; I paid for that straw.

Q. I need hardly ask you, whether up to this instant you ever owed him for goods sold or delivered, or for any thing, the sum of 500l? A. I never did, I swear so most positively; I am living on my fortune, the result of my service in India.

Cross-examined by MR. ALLEY. Q. Do not you know that the defendant has a farm, for which he pays 200l. a year rent? A. He had nothing to do with the farm - it was his mother's; she is now dead: the defendant is a member of the yeomanry corps of the County, which is commanded by Lord Grantham; I have heard he was an overseer of the poor - the action for 130l. was settled before the declaration was filed; I paid the costs.

Q. Was there not a receipt in full, demanded of the defendant, before the money was paid, and did not he refuse to give it? A. Not before the money was paid; I only know that from what I learned from those who were engaged in the business - I instructed my attorney to demand a receipt in full, but never got it; I had paid him money before the 130l. in 1825 and 1826, under circumstances of threats; I paid him various sums - I paid him 200l. at Aberford, in 1825.

Q. Did you happen to meet him on the 7th of November, 1824, at a place, not at your house? A. I did on the road to York, in a field - I had a person with me; I was walking - I had not been sitting down at all; the person with me was the defendant's brother - he is now living: I have not brought him here - I did not request the defendant to call at my house the next day; my brother-in-law went to him with that request, in consequence of the representation I made to him - my brother-in-law is not here: I saw the defendant at my house on the afternoon of that day - nobody was present at the interview, not even my brother-in-law.

Q. Did you not request the defendant, for God's sake, not to repeat to any body what he had seen the day before, but to keep it secret? A. I did not, on my oath - I positively swear I did not tell him I must make him a friend, and if he would keep it secret I would introduce him among gentlemen in the country.

Q. Am I to understand you to swear you did not at that time solicit him to keep a secret for you? A. He obtained money from me - from the nature of his threats, I paid him money; I did not solicit him to keep a secret - nothing was said to him about keeping a secret; I swear that positively: there was a Bible in the room, and it might be on the table - there were very likely other books there, for the conversation was in my study.

Q. Did you not at that time ask him to swear on the Bible that he would keep the secret? A. When he had received the money - he had received the money - I do not recollect whether it was before he had received it, that I asked him.
Q. Did he swear on the Bible? A. He might have done so - Yes, he did; he swore he would not mention any thing which, of course, would have affected my character.

Q. Any thing he had seen the day before? A. Any thing he might devise for money; he swore he would not make any more demands for money; this was in November, 1824 - my brother-in-law, Mr. Thompson, was in the neighbourhood at the time; the prisoner was there a very short time - I did not ask him to take some wine: he might be treated hospitably, as any other person, by my servants; he was not treated with cake and wine - he lived about three-quarters of a mile off; I did not put any thing into his pocket - I put the money into his hand - I keep a butler, footman, and other servants.

Q. Did you happen to leave home at that time for a few months? A. I was going a journey; I went to Scarborough, with a niece who was ill - I was there about two months; I returned home for a few days - my niece asked me to accompany her to the South, and I went; on my return home, I stopped at the
Morris Arms
, Aberford, a few miles from my house - it is the principal inn; my lady and niece were with me - I did not send for the prisoner to come there to me; I waited for him - I found him there; I had not sent him word that I was coming home - I was not in correspondence with him.
Q. Did he not come there in consequence of an invitation - no matter how it was conveyed? A. Yes - I saw him in the principal sitting-room; my niece was walking in the garden; my wife was present.

Q. Did you not there, in the presence of your wife, request him to take an oath that he would still keep the secret? A. I made no request - he did take an oath; the Bible might be in one corner of the room, or probably it was on the table: I did not promise to give him 250l., and promise a further payment of 500l. to him - I did not prosecute him for extorting the money in 1824; I had a little boy named Cooper in my service, he is the son of a poor woman in the neighbourhood: he lived with me about seven years, and left to better his situation; my wife is here. On my oath, I did not request the prisoner, that if he should arrest me for 500l., to say that it was for goods sold and delivered; I did not see him, and never said a word on the subject to him, nor has any body by my authority - I have not seen him to speak to him for three years and a half.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. In what state of health is your brother-in-law, Mr. Thompson, at this instant? A.
